Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical and Numerical Studies of Nonlocal Equations Derived from Stochastic Differential Equations with Levy Noises
Award.AbstractNarration:
Stochastic effects are ubiquitous in complex systems in science and engineering. Although random mechanisms may appear to be very small or very fast, their long time impact on the system evolution may be delicate or even profound, which has been observed in, for example, stochastic bifurcation, stochastic resonance and noise-induced pattern formation. The research team will study the complex systems under uncertainty by developing numerical methods to be simulated on computers and answer fundamental questions about the average quantities of the systems. The investigators will deliver the following broader impact outcomes: (1) Two graduate students (including one female underrepresented minority) will receive education and training and (2) they will continue to recruit and nurture underrepresented students in STEM. Additionally, the resulting computational tools have broad applications in areas ranging from biology to geophysics. The software resulting from the proposed project will be made publicly available.

Mathematical modeling of complex systems under uncertainty often leads to stochastic differential equations (SDEs). Fluctuations appeared in the SDEs are often non-Gaussian (e.g., Levy motions) rather than Gaussian (e.g., Brownian motion). Compared with systems with Gaussian noises, quantifying the impacts of non-Gaussian Levy fluctuations are much less understood. The researchers will develop convergent and efficient numerical techniques for investigating the deterministic macroscopic quantities that can help understand the dynamics of SDEs with Levy noises, in particular the mean exit time, escape probability, and probability density function. They will also answer theoretical questions with regard to the well-posedness and the regularity of the solutions to these nonlocal equations. Building upon previously developed methods in the one-dimensional case, the team will focus its effort on two-dimensional systems. The proposed project will provide not only broadly applicable computational techniques to solve integro-differential equations with singular integrands, but also theoretically address the central questions pertaining to the solutions. The theory will help to provide insight into fundamental issues in quantifying the impacts of non-Gaussian Levy fluctuations in dynamical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project include (1) developing convergent and efficient numerical techniques for investigating the deterministic macroscopic quantities that can help understand the dynamics of SDEs with alpha-stable Levy noises, in particular the mean exit time, escape probability, and probability density function; (2) analysing the effects of the non-Gaussian noises in biological sciences; (3) answering theoretical questions with regard to these nonlocal equations.

In this reporting period of Sept 1st, 2019 to August 31st, 2020, the PIs have finished developing a convergent and efficient numerical algorithm for solving the mean exit time, escape probability, and probability density function arised from the SDEs with alpha-stable Levy noise. They have investigated nonlocal dynamics of the non-Gaussian systems in a gene regulatory network. The PIs have also developed a Hamiltonian formalism under the Levy fluctuations with exponentially light jumps for one- and two-dimensional dynamical systems, based on a large deviation principle. They also combined machine learning from data and stochastic dynamics to learn and understand stochastic dynamics based on data. This method is applicable to sample path data collected from complex systems, as long as these systems can be modeled as SDEs. The PIs have studied an averaging principle for fractional SDEs with Levy motion using an integral transform method and obtained a time-averaged effective equation under suitable assumptions. 

During the reporting period of 2019-2020, the PIs have published the following peer-reviewed journal articles:

  1. T. Wang, X. Li and H. Wang, An error estimate of a {E}ulerian-{L}agragian localized adjoint method for a space-fractional advection diffusion equation, Int. J. of Numer. Anal. Model, 17(2)  (2020), 151--170. 

  2.  R. Cai, Z. He, Y. Liu, J. Duan, J. Kurths and X. Li, Effects of Levy noise on the FitzHugh-Nagumo model: A perspective on the maximal likely trajectories, J. of Theoretical Biology, 480 (2019), 166--174. 

  3.  Dengfeng Wu, Miaomiao Fu and Jinqiao Duan, Discovering mean residence time and escape probability from data of stochastic dynamical systems. Chaos 29, 093122 (2019)

  4.  Xiaoli Chen and Jinqiao Duan, Nonlocal Dynamics for Non-Gaussian Systems Arising in Biophysical Modeling. Communications on Applied Mathematics and Computation (2020) 2:201 - 213. 

  5.  Wenjing Xu, Jinqiao Duan, and Wei Xu, An averaging principle for fractional stochastic differential equations with L?vy noise Chaos 30, 083126 (2020).

  6.  Yang Li, Jinqiao Duan, Xianbin Liu, and Yanxia Zhang. Most probable dynamics of stochastic dynamical systems with exponentially light jump fluctuations. Chaos 30, 063142 (2020).

We have presented our research results in the following national and international conferences: 

  1. May 7--9, 2020, SIAM Conference on Mathematics of Data Science, Cincinnati, Ohio.  Extracting stochastic governing laws from data by a nonlocal Kramers-Moyal formula; Invited to speak online at the Minisymposium on  Mathematical Issues in Machine Learning. 

  2. January 15-18, 2020, Joint Mathematics Meetings, Denver, Colorado.  Most Probable Transition Pathways in Stochastic Dynamical Systems.  Invited presentation at the Special Session on Stochastic Differential Equations.

  3. October 2, 2019.  Dynamical Systems Plus Data Science: What Can We Learn?  Data Science Seminar, Johns Hopkins University.

  4. July 15--19, 2019. The 9th International Congress on Industrial and Applied Mathematics, Valencia, Spain.  Speaker in  `Dynamics of   Stochastic Partial Differential Equations via Effective Reduction'. 

  5. July 8--12, 2019.    The 41st Conference on Stochastic Processes and their Applications (SPA19), Northwestern University. Invited session organizer for Stochastic Dynamics.
